column11: Review Text

Kudumbigala is a beautiful place,  and the climb to the top is highly recommended. The walk through the forest and huge rocks is peaceful and serene and contact with nature could not be better. Its altogether a unique and soul satisfying experience. Be quiet and respectful of the surroundings when you walk, so that neither nature nor the resident monks are disturbed. The place is a gem

Extraordinary site! You don't have to just climb to the top of the rock. Follow the path that goes to the left of the temple under the cave and you will discover a treasure! Too bad some idiots didn't understand anything and took the liberty of engraving the rock with their initials! Revolting, stupid, as useless as those who committed this act! Let's respect this historic site! THANKS
Great place to visit. Interesting place lovely walks in area. Recommend walk up to viewing point where the 360 degree views are stunning.
really enjoyed place arugambay Such a nature place best Great place definitely recommend arugam bay any body go there super place
What an amazing hike. Fabulous views. Spend as much time as possible at the top. take water and snack but do not litter please

In 2016 , this placw as sacred and unknown for tourist world. We have gained so many beautiful moments and wisdom from this place so please even today, when its open to public, be kind and silence in your presence. How I miss this magical energy!!
Its a nice place those who seeks quite calm Buddhist temple. jungle with wild creatures. no halm so far to any one go there or who do meditation .do not go to enjoy. just go to learn something.

column8: Rock climbing off the beaten route
column11: No entrance fee! and it's a beautiful place, nature walk , with lots of wildlife and special atmosphere. it;s an holy place so the atmosphere is quite spiritual.

column6: hayat tours and taxi service arugambay
column11: Kudumbigala Monastery lies eleven miles from Panama and seventeen miles away from the Kumana Village. Kudumbigala monastic complex was built in 246 BC, during the time of King Devanampiyatissa. It was first established as a refuge for the Buddhist monks who wanted to get away from the busy Cities. Archaeologists had recovered over 200 rock caves belonging to this forgotten monastery.
This is one of most ancient cave temple in east cost sri lanka.. middle of the kumana national park..lot to see wildlife and nature ..

This visit was our 4th Annual arms giving to the monastery. Like I mentioned several time when reviewed about this place, This place is a monastery which has got full of ancient ruins & caves like olden days,still monks live & meditating there & our visits  have to be respect for the rules that are given by the monastery. This place is not a place you can go there and have fun!!!! You can visit there & enjoy the beauty of this place but always try to obey the rules which are going to be favor for the monks who live there and meditate. ðŸŒ¹So dress properly ðŸŒ¹No alcohol be taken to the premises ðŸŒ¹Visit appropriate times noted ðŸŒ¹Respect surrounding environment by not standing on Stupa that we are worshipping & other ancient ruins.... ðŸŒ¹Always try to be quiet when visiting

you need a good condition to climb all the way up to the highest point but the view is great and all the caves provide a lot of history. It is a surprisingly well maintained area and the help of stairs makes it much easier to reach the upper level. I felt really rewarded for all the Climbing in the heat of the day.

We booked a 2 pm tuk tuk to do an afternoon tour. Its about 16 km on paved rd to Panama from Arugam Bay. It is then another 10 km on very bumpy dirt road to the Kudumbigala Monastery. A 1600 year old Budda sits in a cave. You then walk/climb the side of a huge boulder/rock to the stuppa at the top. Do-able in flip flops. The view up there is amazing. We then went to the beach just past the Kumana National Park entrance another 5 km. We started back about 4:30 seeing elephants, mongoose, wild boar, deer, many birds and crocodiles. All for 2,500 Rs. The dirt road was the biggest challenge.

There are limited activities in arugam bay as it is currently the off season. Pretty much, it's hard to get to this monastery and we had our driver drive us to panama (the town the monastery is located) and we had to get a tuktuk for the rest of the trip (which is pretty much 30min of uneven bumpy road. Please please note; this is a religious site so dress appropriately, cover up your shoulders and legs!! We opted to do the walk at 430 for sunset, so had to leave arugam bay 330pm. The walk itself is pleasant, it took us roughly 1.5hrs maybe less, it only becomes tough in the last 5minutes as it becomes quite vertical (descending is hard for people with bad knees but it's quite short so just toughen up). I brought my runners which had good grip but our driver did it in barefoot the whole way haha and the other guy did it in jandals (I probably would just recommend sensible running shoes). Anyway the view from the top was AMAZINGLY MIND BLOWING, it was so peaceful and serene as we were the only people doing the walk. It was cool taking a guide because he told us random stories but you can definitely do the walk without a guide/driver. Oh my biggest regret was not taking a proper camera!!!

It takes a while to get there (both with the car/tuktuk as well as the climb itself which is quite steep) but once you reach the top itâ€™s totally worth it!!! For us best part of our sightseeing trip around Arugam Bay

Our recent visit to Kudumbigala Monastery made me sad to see how resident monks are struggling to control bad behaviours of some foreign visitors with local guides disrespecting & disobeying rules of this valuable, peaceful & beautiful scared place... Among those, â€¢Visiting the monastery out of visiting hours. â€¢Taking & Drinking Alcohol in the Monastery area which is totally prohibited by the monastery rules. â€¢Taking pictures while climbing on Stupa (Ancient scared Ruins) & show disrespectful. â€¢ Dress inappropriately (not covering your self properly) â€¢Entering the premises to the Monastery (Where the monks live & Scared Stupa situated) with shoes on (clearly mention on boards the areas that you should remove your shoes) As a traveller I have been to many countries & have been visited beautiful places. Every country got their own rules & regulations should obey by the foreign visitors to protect their valuable places, Every visitor must respect the places where ever you visit by obeying the rules. This way you will be protecting these beautiful places for the future travellers. If you are a foreign traveller planning to visit this Monastery please respect the rules even though the local guides go easy on Monastery rules. BE A RESPECTABLE TRAVELLER NOT A SELFISH TRAVELLER !!!!!!!!!!!! Also remember this attraction is not a place for the fun & boozing, if you are after those, please find another place....plenty out there other than this scared place where monks are meditating all the time in the jungle area in their Kutis that they need peace & quite all the time. Thank You

You should feel how monks live, read the history about the monastery then go. Or take a good guide who will tell. It is allowed to walk inside the village but only bearfoot and also scilent. It is forbidden to talk. One of the best places that saw in Sri Lanka.

We were awe-struck by the views at the top and deeply humbled by the monastery. It was a short but difficult climb to do barefoot and silent on coarse rock in extreme heat, and left lasting impressions on us. Amazing views. We even spotted a couple of Tuskers en route from the area! A very worthy landmark to pay visit to.

The monastery is located or hidden at a corner of the island surrounded by a national sanctuary. An ideal place for abstract meditation. Amazing feeling when you climbed the rock. Most peaceful eco system in the south east corner of the island

This is a must go place in Ampara District. Hard to climb to the top, but you will never regret after going up. There is a ruined temple up on the rock. Also very scenic views up there. On the way to Kudumbigala, you can find some deer, elephants, crocodiles and few more wild animals.

I spent the day in a tuk tuk exploring parts of the national park and finished by waling to the top of this monastery to watch the sunset. It's a pretty extraordinary place and my top pick for Arugam Bay

The road to the Monastery is really nice and if you are lucky you can see some deers and elephants (you can't be on the road too early in the morning  or too late in the afternoon as they are too many elephants crossing and it could be dangerous).The walk up to the monastery is   enjoyable and you will meet some monks on your way.The view on top is stunning!

If you need to fill half a morning/evening at arugam bay then would definitely recommend coming to visit the monastery! It's an hour tuk tuk journey away and the drive takes you through the start of the national park so you get to see a variety of animals and birds along the way. A round trip should cost around 3000 rupees per tuk tuk. It's not a hard climb up once you arrive, most of the way up is through tree cover though it is bare rock right at the top for the last five minutes of the climb. Make sure you take the path up from the red sign that tells you No hats shoes etc. If you go past the sign it takes you to another shrine (begumbala) which is worth visiting but doesn't have nice views. The view at the top is amazing! We went up at around 8:30am and it was already scorching hot so would recommend getting there as early as possible. It would probably be amazing for sunrise/sunset. You need to have your knees and shoulders covered as with all other temples in Sri Lanka.

Reach the summit just before sunrise, and thank me later. You get a 270 degree view of the wilderness, the ocean, river...from an ancient stupa. The stupa is unique but not particularly awe-inspiring for me. But the climb, the surroundings and the view was great. And there are a few other lovely spots too, perfect for meditation if you're into it, or just bask in the beauty either way. It's a short trek/climb of moderate difficulty. not advisable during rain. Get a tuktuk and leave from Arugam Bay with at least an hour to spare before sunrise. And if you're lucky enough to get a hold of Nipuna from Panama village to take you, your experience will be a good one.
Thousand-year-old Buddhist temple / meditation is to fit a hundred caves, located near some eighty / quiet is a forest.

We went early in the morning it was serene and calm a beautiful place for spent some time on your own. Nice place to meditate. Its a Buddhist temple so dress well and behave decently. The view surround is a treat to eyes

This monastery is so unique that as far as you might travel you will never find a more remarkable place sich as this. Two high mountain peaks. Hard to climb. But with awesome views as a reward. NO money demanded at all - by anyone. Just get yourself up there and write a better review - if you can.

The manager from our accommodation did a scooter trip with us to the temple. I didn't expected very much but this was amazing! When you climb up to the top of the rock you can see the jungle, rocks and the coastline. It was one of the most beautiful places I ever been to. If you're thinking about doing it - DO IT!
one of the most peaceful and resting place also it can make your soul rest for a time forget from your busy life style,  dress cord is long because it is a monastery no short dress.
Even it was raining, can see many kinds of birds & animals. So exciting for jeep safari. If there is an introduction before start the trip is more better.
Visited here whilst on honey moon last year, we were amazed with the views from the top after a steep walk in the heat. it was so peaceful and calm.
Nthing to add to all other reviews. Apart from the fact that it's far better to climb up during any of those fine, mild and usually dry Winter months! Summers are simply too hot and sticky.

Its near to the Kumana National Park.You should go in the morning or the evening to visit this place.Other times feel very hot.But don't go after 5 pm .You can faced with wild elephants. You can find some historical ruins in side the area.You should wear proper dress & also should be silence. Its really unique place .Surrounding is very beautiful and relaxing.

we drove our hired car in the dark from Arugambay to this wonderful place ... can recommend an early morning swim at Peanut farm on the return journey too ... we did it all before breakfast ... Magical ... there were two other people at the top, we guess it got busy later, our arrival time was 5.55am !  Would do it all again ! We enjoyed the peacocks and monkeys on the road back . 20 kms down a track after turning right after the Buddhist temple, 20kms i think but it didnt like you could go wrong. ... the correct road turns into a dust track after 300 metres.

Kudumbigala Monastery is a mystic place. When you arrive at the top of this rock, after walking through the jungle you feel alone in Sri Lanka. You feel the earth and its power, you feel small in front of it and in front of human history.

This is a must do! Simply amazing views for sun set and sun rise atop a hill top monastery that is over 1000 years old and still inhabited by monks today! Tip, don't go in the afternoon as its blazing hot and you need to hike a bit. Dawn and dusk are best.

I went here from Arugam Bay, at 3am with a tuktuk driven by a guide recommended by Hideaway. The adventure started only a few miles down the way where the road was blocked by a young bull elephant â€“ well, that's what the driver said, I wasn't going anwhere near enough to verify either age or gender. It got chased off by a lorry that we then slipstreamed and then arrived near the monastery where we joined a line of pilgrims carrying goods to the monks. We split from them and then went onto the rocks, and I took off my shoes as ordered by my guide. Up there the views were quite extraordinary and imposing, while the guide pointed out the many caves where monks had once lived, the pools in the rocks where they would have bathed, and the rock that was in the shape of the Buddha sleeping. And then to the monastery itself, which wasn't quite as impressive as the surrounding rocks. These rise above the forest and the sea so that watching the sun come up is exquisite. Not a particularly tourist like spot, from what I could see. I was the only European and there were no shops or cafes.

Imam and Mahroof from Mooneyes sorted this spectacular trip out for us. Quick aside I recommend you use Mahroof of Kiwi safari for any of the local trips. He is a wonderful guy and his English is fantastic. This is a climb. You drive half way into the national park on a bumpy road. From here you take a side road through dense forest. All around the insects, monkeys and birds make the kinds of noises you've only ever heard in jungle films. Upon arrival lock up anything safe as if you don't the monkeys will have it. The monkeys are very tame and will come extremely close to you but do beware. These are still wild animals and they've been known to jump on people and on rare occasions to bite. Neither happened to us but it is worth being mindful of the possibility. We started with a gentle incline through forest and rock to get to the current monastery. This is gorgeously situated at the top of a medium sized hill. Along the way you see and hear amazing scenes of nature and the old buildings. The view is spectacular with ponds full of frogs, forest, valleys and more. We then headed back down and at the cave entrance we took a different fork and headed up a much steeper climb. As we turned the corner from a tough bit of flat rock and forest we were greeted with an extremely steep set of very small stairs heading up flat rock. My youngest son and my wife got half way up the first small section before having to turn back. The rest of us pressed on. Now I'm a little out of shape but not unfit (I've completed 3 triathlons and a couple of 5k runs this year) but this was quite tough. When we got half way I had to take a break. The heat and humidity didn't help but... the views... At the top you see the ancient stipa and you get the most amazing views I've seen in a very long time. This is totally worth it. I would happily have simply sat there meditating on the view alone for hours if it wasn't for my middle son wanting to get back down (plus those left behind getting restless). This is beautiful and worth it.

It might seems a long trip to access the monastery but the view at the top is worth it! And you will see many animals on the way (Crocodiles, Elephants, Peacocks...)You will have a panoramic view of the jungle and the ocean. The top is not very easy to access as you need to leave your shoes before climbing. When we went there was a lot of wind which was a bit scary... Downstairs you will see a lot of monkeys. For women do not forget long piece of clothes...

We visited this during our 'tuk tuk safari' one afternoon and the history of the place is very interesting.  I then did the climb up to the top of the rock mountain where you had a 360 degree view for miles.  I didn't think it was going to be worth the visit but the view alone makes it worth the effort.

Went early as very hot. The drive in is fine for car, a few bumps but you don't need tuk tuk or jeep. Lots of peacocks in way and bird life amazing in swamp area. This monastery has beautiful cave for meditation and stupa like sarnath in India on top. The natural rocks look like sleeping Buddha . Walk to top has steps cut and  chain. 14 monks still living here. A beautiful site if you are moved by Buddhist tradition and also views from top of surrounds for the nature lovers. Wear runners and you need sarong or long pants. Water would have been a good idea

Every year in January we visit this Monastry to do the arms giving ( offering food) to the resident monks who practis meditation. There is walk from the base to the top of the rock.. Girls please remember to cover your self to the full when you visit the site. Also try to be quiet during the walk to respect the monks who are meditating in their "Kuti's" If you are in Arugam Bay make a drive to this Monastry, you won't regret the experience.
Panama is very calm and quite village and kudumbigala is an amazing place to relax. PanamPattu managed homestay people helped us to get there its really a nice place
We experienced bear invasion in the night!! Stayed one night for a alms giving . Nice place midst of the jungle with views of wildlife on the route, elephants!!!

Come here late afternoon with a motorcycle and on your way back to Arugam Bay you will see many elephants, crocodiles, dear, hare, rabits, etc. The animals get hydrated before the sunset. Be careful not to approach the elephants though!

Very interesting trip that may take up to half of the day. Although located pretty far from nearby villages and took around 1 hour for us to get there from Arugam Bay by tuk-tuk, it is worth going. It is very peaceful and quiet place with nice ambiance and beautiful views.

This is a calm,quite place enriched with natural beauty which is said to be a center of meditation for the monks. There is a temple with Buddha statues, a cave,ruins on the top of the rock which is accessed through stone steps. We were soaking with sweat when we reached the top but the panoramic view from the top and  the wind were like  rewards. We also offered alms to the monks. This is a  very good place for taking photos as well.

Trip advisor map location is way off mark.  It is about 40km away from arugam bay over the other side of Panama near the national park.  As some mentioned the road is a bit rough, the best to go is with a motorcycle.  Along the way from arugam bay one can see a lot of birds and animals.

Kudumbigala monastery located in the middle of thick jungle said to have been built in 246 BC in a land of boulders Kudumbigala is one of the wonderful places I have ever explored. It is an old monastery which had been re-discovered in recent past. Most fascinatingly, it has become one of the most interior monasteries, where Theravadhi Buddhist monks are occupying under very basic facilities. They just focus on their meditation and ignore the life threats that would come at anytime through a wild animal, especially from sloth bears. They just live a very basic life in the monastery, which is surrounded by bushes and beasts. They say that they are not attacked by any of the animals since they practice the meththa of Buddhist teaching all the way

The road out to the monastery is quiet rough, which makes for an uncomfortable tuk tuk ride. Four or better still 2 wheels would have been better! The trip is however worth it to see this ancient monument and climb to the top for spectacular views.

We landed at Kudumbigala just for a lark, spent a good hour at the top taking in the lovely vistas spread before us....verdant green forest...with huge rocks breaking the green carpet......mountains.....the ocean in the distance Its quite scenic An easy walk up...i had a sprained ankle still made it up....would recomend good footwear thou Best time to visit is day break,.....but we made it up in the eve...still lovely.... Make sure you dont stay late thou....leave with enough daylight to make it down

The  spectacular view alone worth a visit- gorgeous big boulders and a serene energy - a magic place to meditate (if you are into meditation) a small temple at the bottom - the nature and view is why you would visit ...

We rented a Scooter to go there from arugam bay. It way quite a long ride (40min) through the middle od the jungle. Lots of animals crossed our way - which way nice. But the monastery itself wasnt worth visiting. There are way more beautiful Tempels and sights to see in Sri lanka without paying a lot of money for a tuk tuk ride or a scooter.
Isolated and on the beach with Elephants roaming and Peacocks calling - plenty of monkeys in the area as well

Visit this amazing spiritually inspiring place. Quickly! Before it become yet another spoiled, expensive tourist trap (like the Kandy Temple). For now it's FREE. And the view from the two heights is breath taking.
short walk up to the temple. The view from there is not exceptional. Lots of people come there to the temple

If you are in the Arugam bay  area really worth the visit. Peaceful place in the middle of vegetation. Very good to enjoy the sense of vastity from the top. Interesting for wildlife as well as we spotted monkeys and wildlife along the way. The highlight of the day was being surprised by a rainstorm just as we reached the top... quite scary but definitively an adventure to remember.
not to far from arugam bay, wonderful view on the top o rock, peaceful place, small monastery, beautiful rocks, worth to climb on the rock and enjoy the sunset

This is not a destination point and never made our bucket list.  Yet, if you are in Arugam Bay and looking for a place to visit while resting up after spending time on one of Sri Lanka's quiet and serene beaches, this site is worth the visit.

The way to the monestary is beautiful, with many birds and bumpy roads. We didn't see the caves around, although the atmosphere is quite magical. Lots of monkeys in the place. There's a walk up the rocks and you can climb the big one, with the budha statue on top. Even 3 years old did that without too much effort. The views from the top are amazing, of all the area! It might be nicer at sunset, we were there at midday, due to lack of planning

30 minutes drive from Arugam Bay, either with a bike or a tuktuk, Kudimbigala Temple is really worth the trip either early morning or for sunset. Breathtaking 360Â° view on the National park, jungle, lagoon and Okanda beach.

Like a previous reviewer we also went with Jaya from Hideaway . He is a very spiritual Man with good English and our afternoons trip was a highlight - first we visited some beautiful wetlands where we saw beautiful bird life and crocodiles with huge tracts of flowering water lilies . The monastery grounds were looked over by this enormous rock which we climbed . It was quite perilous at times but well worth it for the view Highly recommended if not a bit of a bumpy ride

More interesting way to monastery than monastery. Along the way you can see many birds (peacocks, ibises, storks, kingfishers and herons) and a antelope. It's small monastery, don't have ancient artworks. It's located in 12 km from Panama village by national park road, 2 km far by main road (sign 14 km) located good beach (but for good swimmers only), 1 km more located small popular Hindu temple (at national park entrance), there's available food and drink points.

We hired an amazing Tuk Tuk driver called Jaya to take us. He was as much to do with the trip as the monastery. You can find him by going to hideaway resort, they  will hook you up. Being a Buddhist, Jaya's understanding and so his information was from his soul. Making our visit very beautiful. The walk to the top of the Rock is a must. The view is amazing. Across to the ocean and over the national forest. It also gives you a great perspective on the lay out of the hermitage. A very magical and spiritual place, that you feel privileged to get a glimpse of.

Kudumbigala has a unique shape and the rock stands like a giant among other rocks in the area. trekking barefooted is challenging but that is what we did! we think that gives you a deep feeling of grounded, rootedness to its surrounding. when you climb to the very peak it gives a magnificent panoramic view over the horizon leaving you speechless. a silent walk through the monastery area where monks are in meditation is a great calming experience as well. i would recommend to start the trekking in the early morning specially if you are walking barefoot! be silent and be at peace!

This is a very good place indeed. Nice sceneries, wild life, etc... But this is a place dedicated for those who enjoy the silence and peace. There are people who stay in this place and practicing meditation for months. So if you go there enjoy your visit mindfully.

I love Kudumbigala Monastery! It represents all that I love about Sri Lanka : it is simple, humble, honest, and spiritually fulfilling. I would recommend sunrise or sunset. If you are hiking to the highest rock you will want sneakers or bare feet (I always do it barefoot). But with that in mind, the rocks get SUPER hot as they bake in the sun all day, so be mindful if you are going later in the day. enjoy!

I have been to this place few time with my friends from abroad and Sri Lanka. we enjoy scenic view from the top of the rock. The path that leads to where the ancient monastery is interesting. If you like to listen to the sounds of nature this is one of the places I would recommend. Dress modestly,respect the quietness and observe the beautiful place. It is better if you can start to climb the rock early morning so as to avoid the heat. Very good in evening to watch the sun sets. You may able to see wild elephants if you do the trip evening. You can travel by your own vehicle or rent a tuk tuk,don't try on motor bike in the evening.(because of the elephants). Don't miss this trip if you are planning to come to Arugambay.
The peace & Quiet. Tranquility. Meditation. This is a holy place - with NO commercial interests at all. Lucky. So far!

Kudumbigala Forest Monastery is situated in the far end of the Eastern Province in Ampara district. Its 398 km from Colombo. Closest town is Panama. From there its 23 km . Best place to learn practice spirituality and meditation in this universe. As a priest or yoga or as lay man you can practice spirituality or meditation. This place has been a forest monastery for thousands years too. But recent past in 1968 . With LTTE attacks during civil war this place was hit severely. When you go there don't forget to visit Bambaragastalawa Forest monastery. That also belongs to the above monastery. Its another 23 km by vehicle towards Kumana national park or by walk just with in 3-4 hours you can reach there.

Amazing visit a few hours before sunset allowed us to hike the trails out of the heat but before the darkness, hear the birds and do some yoga on top of the rocks while just feeling the wind and tranquil 360 degree views of the forest and sea below.
It is Buddah temple and a Monastery in the Jungle with full of nature and an ideal place to learn the teaching of Lord Buddah and a best location for spiritual mediation.
